trial_identification.studytitle: Sub-chronic administration of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor escitalopram in healthy volunteers: drug initiation effects and the role of serotonin in experimental anxiety.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect in healthy volunteers of administration of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor escitalopram (10 mg/day for 3 weeks) vs. placebo on drug initiation effects and experimentally-induced anxiety.

conditions.healthcondition: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) initiation effects

interventions.interventions: escitalopram (10 mg/day for 3 weeks, oral) tryptophan depletion

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in the Spielberger State Anxiety Inventory in the placebo and escitalopram groups
Change in Visual Analogue Scale scores (anxiety, nervous) in the placebo and escitalopram groups

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-drug, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks and 3 weeks post drug initiation

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: healthy volunteer no current or previous history of anxiety, depression or mental illness
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: current or past mental illness current or past use of SSRI medication pregnant/breastfeeding serious medical condition history of head injury history of drug abuse/dependence

trial_design.concealment: Participants are screened by study doctors. Once deemed eligible to participate, they will be assigned a study number that corresponds to study medication bottles.
trial_design.sequence: placebo and escitalopram order randomly assigned in blocks using a random number generator (www.random.org)

fundingsource.fundingname: University of Western Australia Small Grants Scheme 2007

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether the effect of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors seen when used to treat anxiety are related to the drug, or to the fact that the people have an anxiety disorder. We expect that we will see "jitteriness" when healthy volunteers start taking the medication, and that the medication will reduce anxiety brought on by an experimental challenge in people who do not have an anxiety disorder.
